article.title: Boolean Unateness Testing with $\widetilde O(n^{3/4})$ Adaptive Queries

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the binary search strategy aim to find in the context of Boolean function unateness testing?
choices: A pair of points with the same function value.
A monotone edge in the Boolean hypercube.
A bi-chromatic edge in the Boolean hypercube.

multiple_choice_question.text: What crucial condition must hold for AE-Search(x, S) to successfully return index \'i\' with high probability?
choices: The edge (x, x(i)) must be an anti-monotone edge.
The majority of subsets T ⊂ S with i ∈ T have f(x(T)) = f(x(i)).
The set S must contain all indices where x and x(i) differ.
The function f must be monotone within the sub-cube containing x.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key advantage of AE-Search over a naive search for bi-chromatic edges?
choices: AE-Search guarantees finding all bi-chromatic edges connected to x.
AE-Search always identifies the direction of a bi-chromatic edge.
AE-Search uses significantly fewer queries, especially for large S.
AE-Search doesn\'t require knowing the function value at x beforehand.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Alg-Case-1, what does an empty intersection of sets A and B signify?
choices: An edge violation is found, indicating non-unateness.
